body:
I confirmed that the problem is not the padding it is something else. If you remove the padding in the last version of the library you get the following error that has to do with the internal sizes of the matrixes:

``` bash
`InferShape Error in ch_concat_3c_chconcat: [09:25:44] src/operator/./concat-inl.h:152: Check failed: (dshape[j]) == (tmp[j]) Incorrect shape[2]: (576,320,13,13). (first input shape: (576,576,14,14))
```

If you roll back to commit `c3edd8d75c0b9221c2a808da9b755fad1e27249e` the error dispears

I do the same experiment, I once got top1 near 50% on validation set, but now retrain fail to near 13%..., did you know what is the problem?
my dataset is around 1400w, classes number=5190
A strange error. You can use `otool -L lib/libmxnet.so` to view the library dependencies.
I don't understand. @sxjscience I haven't use target_shape in rnn-char.py, so where should I replace target_shape using shape ? Thanks for your time.
@CodePothunter Try to find all the `mx.sym.Reshape` operations and replace the old onew with `mx.sym.Reshape(..., shape=(...))`

../../tools/launch.py -H hosts -n 2 --launcher ssh export DMLC_INTERFACE=ib0; export DMLC_NUM_WORKER=2; export DMLC_NUM_SERVER=2; export DMLC_ROLE=worker; python train_imagenet.py --network inception-bn --gpus 0,1,2,3 --batch-size 256 --num-epochs 1 --data-shape 224 --data-dir ../../data/ilsvrc12/ --kv-store dist_async

The errors are the same no matter I use dist_sync or dist_async.

for info, `nvidia-docker run -it --rm kaixhin/cuda-mxnet:7.0 python example/image-classification/train_mnist.py --network lenet --gpus 0` works well. The only difference between `kaixhin/cuda-mxnet` and `kaixhin/cuda-mxnet:7.0` is the the version of CUDA (7.5 vs. 7.0) and cuDNN (5 vs 4).

I built a docker image using CUDA 7.5 and cuDNN 4. It gives the same error. It seems Mxnet has some problems with CUDA 7.5.

Thank you

my problem is similar at your code but it not the same. In my case i have a
single output and different image input. I wrote a stupid network only for
example. In this network data1 and data2 have two image with different
resolution ( course in level "Concat" shapes should be equal, but this just
an example). If i wanted to change code in train_imagenet.py and the
relative code for read image dataset (ImageRecordIter), how can i do?
I have made many tests but without result!

But thank you very much for your response!

get_symbol <- function(num_classes = 1000) {

data1 <- mx.symbol.Variable('data1')
data2 <- mx.symbol.Variable('data2')

conv1 <- mx.symbol.Convolution(data = data1, kernel = c(5, 5), num_filter =
20)

conv2 <- mx.symbol.Convolution(data = data2, kernel = c(10, 10), num_filter
= 50)

tanh1 <- mx.symbol.Activation(data = conv1, act_type = "tanh")

tanh2 <- mx.symbol.Activation(data = conv2, act_type = "tanh")

actf = mx.symbol.concat[tanh1,tanh2];

flatten <- mx.symbol.Flatten(data = actf)

fc1 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = flatten, num_hidden = 500)

tanh3 <- mx.symbol.Activation(data = fc1, act_type = "tanh")

# second fullc

fc2 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = tanh3, num_hidden = num_classes)

# loss

lenet <- mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data = fc2, name = 'softmax')

return(lenet)

}

Thanks a lot for the contribution. It's greatly appreciated.
Made a few comments. Two general points:
1) move everthing mkl related into src/operators/mkl/. In the future we want to move it into plugins/
2) separate mkl installation from mxnet (you can leave a helper script in the root, but it should install mkl to a proper location)

also add author names into all files:
+/*!
- \* Copyright (c) 2015 by Contributors
- \* \file mkldnn_pooling-inl.h
- \* \brief
- \* \author Chen, Xiaoming
  +*/

As I find out, libgdal.so.1 is bound with some libs of OpenCV, so I suspect the problem has something to do with the building of OpenCV.

As a workaround, just disable OpenCV binding when compiling MXNet.

Might close the issue, but still confused what goes wrong since I just follow the instructions.

@pluskid: its passing now. I've noticed this strange situation with the build system: it often seg faults the first time it builds. And then it just works the next time even without any changes. Very strange.

You should use `python setup install` under python directory when you are in your anaconda's virtual env. 

Follow the instruction here: http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/how_to/build.html

``` python
internals = model.symbol.get_internals()
output_layer_you_want = internals['output_layer_name']

new_model = mx.model.create()  # use this api, pass necessary symbol(the output_layer_you_want and aug_param, etc)
new_model.predict()
```

Search and you would find it.
`symbol.list_arguments()` would help you debug.

3) Fix Pooling so it doesn't inherit PoolingOp, return PoolingOp in createoperatorEx if mkldnn doesn't support it
4) Fix test errors and lint

Just let other people know that I have solved this issue in a non-elegant way.
in mxnet/ps-lite/src/van.cc file
I changed the line
if (itf) interface = std::string(itf);
to
interface = std::string("ib0"); // use whatever port you want to use.

Then recompile mxnet and install python library.
It seems the line 
const char\*  itf = Environment::Get()->find("DMLC_INTERFACE");
is a bug, because its value is empty although I set the DMLC_INTERFACE environment variable.

@mli, maybe you can fix this bug later.

Elementwisesum must be called explicitly. It's used for summing up more than 2 arrays

if your input has a symbol called heatmap your data iterator must output that

Hi everyone, William here. I wanted to share a few other color options since I feel strongly about avoiding the green design so that the MXNet logo can be more unique. I added some sample colors and reference to other brands out there to help the group reach a final color choice. To me, in order to stand out, the MXNet logo should use blue or purple as the main color.

@hoaphumanoid You missed a comma. Please update the PR and let's see the testing result.

We need to think about reading sparse inputs from disk too.  Because each record will require variable storage on disk, depending on the number of non-zero entries.  I see a couple of choices here:

1) We adopt a convention like "index=-1 means missing data" and require that all records get -1 padded out to the length of the longest record.  This is simple to implement, and general, but space-inefficient.

2) Write custom InputIter classes that understand how to read variable-length records.
I/O option #1 (padding with -1's) gets much more attractive if the files are gzip encoded.  That's nice in that it's also super general.  (Thanks for the suggestion NB.)

Other changes(fixes) in this PR
- Fix ROIPooling and Correlation's CPU backward because they assume out_grad buffer is zeroed @winstywang 
- Fix the broadcast_to's gradient(previous one won't have correct shape inference because axis parameter is not available in broadcast_to) @piiswrong 
- Fix the matrix op's gpu registration
- Fix warnings in C API ndarray
- Changed sample_op-inl.h to sample_op.h to be consistent with the current style in tensor
- Set _backward_copy.num_outputs to be 1

@tornadomeet Thanks! But what if I don't use any high level api like model or module, instead, only use custom training loop?
then u should use function `get_internals()`, and bind the symbol by yourself, also do fp/bp and print the internal output value by yourself.

I merged in master and test_operator.test_scalar_pow hangs in check_numeric_gradient.
seems like the new check_numeric_gradient cause graph executor to hang at exec.outputs[0].asnumpy()
Could you look into it?

@allankevinrichie It's easy to use monitor in your own training loop.

```
monitor = Monitor(...)
monitor.install(exec)
for i in batch:
   monitor.tic()
   exec.forward()
   exec.backward()
   exec.update()
   monitor.toc_print()
```
